intro: Merathrepta americana, commonly known as the American thornapple, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its spiny stems and showy, violet-blue flowers. The plant produces small, round berries that are toxic to humans but serve as a food source for certain wildlife. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Merathrepta americana typically grows in disturbed soils and is often found in open woods or along roadsides.
